Utilizing an existing replica mauser these are the parts I created to turn it into a replica DL-11.  These are not all the parts you will need to build one, you will obviously need a mauser of some sort and a scope.    The scope was consructed on a lathe out of PVC as well as the heat sink.

All items were originally printed on a printrbot utilizing ABS.  Later, the flash suppressor on the front was reprinted on a makerbot derivative with much better results.  The flash suppressor was printed in ABS at 150 micron layer thickness.  Lightly sanded and finished using acrylic paints.  The source of the files are all my own, created by referencing a lot of pictures so the dimensions may be slightly off as I haven't had hands on a real deal.  You will still need to create a scope and the front heat sink, which could be printed or lathed.  I made mine from pvc pipe on a lathe.  If someome models either, please share it.  I would, but I am all done with the prop and have moved on.

title: Plexiglas LED sign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Having his name illuminated on his desk is one of the coolest things ever !
You can also illuminate yours : you just need an old USB wire, a resistor (140 ohms), an LED and a small plexiglas board (mine is 12 x 7.5 x 1 cm)
Now, you can impress your friends with an enlightened board where you can write your name or anything you want.
It can be a cool way to say "welcome" or to present an important thing (titles in an exhibition, menus in a restaurant, ...) See it work : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9X9svBxAY60&feature=youtu.be Also, if you're interrested, join my discord server to discuss about 3d printing, arduino, processing, ... and find many interresting electronic project ideas : https://discord.me/electronic_projects

An LED powered with 5v may explode...
To prevent this, you need to add a resistor in the circuit (~140 ohms)
I wrote on the plexi with a chalk marker Tip : you can use a fade flashing RGB LED instead of a classic white LED.

comments.author: basile-laderchi

comments.text:
You should really change your LED circuit. You can drive a standard LED from 5v by way of a single resistor. To calculate the resistor you take your input voltage (5), the LEDs stated supply voltage (red LEDs are usually around 2.2), and the max forward current you want to feed the LED (typical is 20mA or .02A). Solving Ohms Law for R you get R (in ohms) = (5-2.2) / .02 = 140. Find a resistor with more than 140 ohms of resistance and place it in series with your LED. Preferably on the 5v input.
Or, you can listen to basile when he comments tomorrow.
comments.author: birdmun

Thank you very much for this. I totally forgot the Ohms Law...
I'll use a single resistor in my next projects.

title: Mr Love cookie cutter and press

description.text: Heart shape biscuit cutter with Mr Love logo press.

You need to have a stiff biscuit dough to press the words into.  It may also be desirable to dust the press with flour to make it easier to prize off the dough.  The heart shape can be cut first and then the words impressed.  It doesn't really need to be guided by the cutter.  I've added a variation of the original cutter/press by making one which produces an outline of the words.  For this variation the heart cutter and word press are part of the same model.

author: paulsroom

description.text:
An adjustable printable knot on a plinth
The first image is a 2,5 knot the other individual one is a 2,3 knot, the other images show some of the knots you can achieve.

I've updated the scad file to allow setting more of the internal parameters to help with building on Windows. If you imagine an invisible torus (donut) with a string going around it, the axisRotation is the number of times the string goes around the top and the radialRotation is the number of times the string goes into the hole and out again. axisRotation = the number of times around the top of the torus
radialRotation = the number of times rotated into the hole
baseHeight = the height of the plinth (0 for no plinth)
numberOfSpheres = the number of spheres used to complete the knot
sphereQuality = larger number = lower the quality see $fs if you would like to produce a series of STL files, you can use the command line options to set the parameters and output file e.g. openscad -s knot15.stl -D "axisRotation = 1" -D "radialRotation = 5" -D "baseHeight = 5" varKnot.scad win32 I had to reduce the resolution of the knots to generate STL files under Windows, the otherwise excellent OpenSCAD couldn't quite manage the originals. This now uses 750Mb or RAM and takes about 3 hours :) I've generated 10 or so STL files so that people without the inclination to use OpenSCAD can still print one. Obviously, I can't generate every possible combination, so please let me know if you'd like some particular combination and I'll see if I can generate the STL file for you.

GuerillaBeam allows you to build powerful modular and portable image projectors. Fits any 35mm lens and various flashlights and speedlights. Fits common 5x5 cm slides with 2mm (Agfa CS) or 2.5mm thickness. Robust 53x3mm threads will attach any 35mm lens and LED lights. An Open Source extension tube is available for creating your own parts. Slots on the inside allow for embedding fresnel lenses (sized 48.5mm x 38.5mm x 0.5mm) or color gels. Use the topmost slot for boosting projection performance with a collecting lens. For more information or buying finished projectors please refer to http://gbeam.de (site is in English).

I usually print it with 0.8mm wall thickness and ~23% fill density.
0.1mm layer thickness is recommended, but you can go up to 0.25mm if you're in a hurry. Support material is required for printing a correctly dimensioned slide slot. Without supports, you will get an ugly slide slot that's way too thin.
See the attached screenshot for an illustration of proper supports.
With Cura, supports will be automagically generated at just the right places by setting overhang angle for support to 51 degrees (Lines support type and 15% fill amount).
With other slicers you should be able to find your own way.

title: TrustFire X8 flashlight adapter for GuerillaBeam

description.text:
The TrustFire X8 is the most recommended light source for GuerillaBeam projectors. This adapter creates a strong connection to the flashlight.
It's easy to print too. See https://gbeam.de/products/adapter-for-trustfire-x8-flashlights/ for additional details. Update 2016-08-06: New revision 11e
  • screw mount instead of clamp mount
  • able to retain the front glass
    • Update 2015-05-16: New revision 4
    Improved fit and printability. Increased length to reduce creep when hot. Also reduced the stress on the 'hinges' for easier assemby with less danger of inadvertently breaking the adapter.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

remixed_from.author: dmyers7
remixed_from.title: DIY Spek DSM2 / DSMX JR Module - For my Taranis & Horus

description.text:
The currently upload design is simply the bay for any JR Tx module.  This was created per a request with the idea that it could be expanded on to create a bay for the back of any radio that does not have a bay for JR Modules.  Once implemented it would give you a PPM cable to plug into your trainer port and allow you to use long range, DSM2, Futaba, ... JR compatible PPM modules with your radio of choice.  It would be velcro'd to the rear of the Tx body.  Yet to be designed is the battery & electronics bay and top flange.  
This is a Work In Progress and I look forward to feedback for mods and adjustments.  It was made from the JR Spek Module I designed with .5mm taken from all surfaces to provide clearance.  Therefore the DIY Spek module should fit and lock in, but I don't know if store bought ones will fit yet; I need help from you on that as I don't currently own anything but the DIY spek module.

comments.text: Great first pass, but looks like its a touch tight so can't get the module in.  IRC EzUHF module measures 44.78mm x 60.35mm (widest - near outside) and 44.4mm x 60mm (furthest in).  The Taranis measures 45mm x 60.5mm furthest out.  The Taranis and modules appear to taper down as they go in, but I'm guessing the tolerances aren't super critical: parallel like you have it will likely work perfectly. The model printed out to 44.25mm x 60.1mm ID.  Another 0.5-0.6mm all around would probably do it.  I can't seem to find my Orange DSMX module to measure it, but will try later tonight.
comments.author: fiveangle

comments.text: so tell me, did you use the irc ezuhf jr module like this with a non jr capable transmitter? does it work? this would be half the price of the external module!
comments.author: fiveangle

comments.text: So the idea was to develop an external jr module case that could be velcro'd to any radio and plugged into the trainer port. The trainer port normally puts out PPM when a radio is placed in slave mode. This is normal protocol that a standard Jr module expects. The items missing from this design are the surrounding housing that would hold a battery, voltage regulator, voltage monitor pin header, and trainer cable. I'd be glad to continue the design if your interested.
comments.author: romanbalsiger

comments.text: I'm very much interested! But i wonder if it's actually working. I googled around and browsed some forums - nobody seems to do that. With the module mentioned above it would be very tempting.
comments.author: dmyers7

comments.text: I would say nobody is doing it because there has not been a commercially available JR Module "bay" available to date to allow for this type of mod.  There is no reason for it not to work, if you think about the TX-R Anylink module it works on the same basis by plugging into the trainer port of any radio to pick up the combined PPM signal and transmit the signal via the Anylink protocol.  The JR Module bay is actually the same and requires a PPM signal standard for modules that are plugged in (the Taranis supports additional protocols through it's bay).  I went as far as looking at the Immersion RC manuals to insure this statement is true; it is looking for a PPM stream to work.  The only odd thing that may occur is that the PPM stream is inverted, but most comply with the Spektrum standard and therefore will work. I guess I can't give you a 100% guarantee, but the everything points to yes it will work.
comments.author: romanbalsiger

comments.text:
so let's try it. i ordered this module:
http://www.immersionrc.com/fpv-products/ezuhf-jr-module/
comments.author: dmyers7

comments.text: Looking forward to your testing too!
comments.author: romanbalsiger

comments.text:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:839581

comments.text: Great to hear and great remix.  Thank you for the feedback.
comments.author: romanbalsiger

comments.text: Let me know what help you need (electrical or case design) to progress.  Looking forward to your testing.
comments.author: romanbalsiger

comments.text: Thanks Dave.  Updated dimensions uploaded.  Final dimensions come in at 45mm and 61mm (I figure the long side is less critical and that will allow the module to slip in easier without binding.  Also included a bottom with a cut-out for the connector.  Bottom is 3mm thick to accommodate the plastic strip on the pin headers which is 3mm thick itself.  Finally, I grew the backend by 0.5mm to allow clearance when plugging in the module so it is not a shoe horn fit and lock for the side tabs.  Have a look and try and we will continue to develop this.

Requires one M5 x 30 mm socket head cap screw and nylon insert lock nut to hold in place on the rail. Camera is offset so as not to interfere with the gunsight.  
Simple version has all sections lined up on front face, print with front face down on printer bed.

The front faces line up, you will need to add support structures to the offset arm only. It is strong enough that the arm could be moved to the front and all lined up, it would make printing easier.  
Required one M5 x 30 mm (minimum) socket head cap screw and M5 nylon insert lock nut to secure to the picatinny rails.

description.text:
My gardener keeps weed wacking the 'Malibu' lamps along the driveway, so I decided to print some replacements.  I made these to use LED's instead of the 12v incandescent lamps the ones from HomeDepot came with.  
The LED's are "superbright" white 5mm sized raw lamps purchased at 1000 pcs for $13 on ebay from some Chinese supplier.  The underground wiring supplies about 8-10v (depending on how far along the line, there is some voltage drop many feet from the transformer).  Each lamp has a string of 4 or 5 LED's in series. A two diode, two capacitor full wave voltage doubler supplies power, and a 7805 or lm117 regulator running in current limiter mode is places in series with the DC power to the LED's.

I printed the top and bottom in Black ABS and the lens in clear ABS.  PLA may work in cooler climates, and it is said to have better UV resistance than ABS.  
Power from the 12v transformer (usually 8-10v at each lamp after voltage drop though 50-100 feet of #18 twin lead cable) is converted to DC with a two diode, two capacitor full wave voltage doubler.  I used 1n4007 diodes, but any 1A Si diode rated at 100PIV or greater will do.  I used 100uf 20v capacitors.  The LED's run at 20ma, so a 7805 regulator with a 270 ohm resistor between the ground and output terminals connected in series between the power supply and LEDs (7805 input to positive, 7805 ground to led string anodes, led string cathodes to minus) will limit the LED current to the required 20ma.  7805's will drive 4 LED's in series.  If you use a LM117(317) regulator then a 68 ohm resistor between ADJ and Output terminals will provide the same results and drive up to 5 series connected LED's.  
The top and bottom parts of the lamp housing are connected using 1" OD PVC irrigation pipe.  Schedule 40 is strong enough to be used unsupported, I used the thinner Schedule 20 with a piece of 3/4" metal EMT inside.  The emt can be hammered into a point to make inserting into the ground easier.  If you printed with ABS, you can use PVC-ABS transition cement to attach the pipe to the printed parts (for PLA use epoxy).  I didn't glue the top on to the pipe, the fit is a tight one and leaving the top removable allows fixing the wiring or replacing a cracked lens.  
The lens was printed using the 'spiral vase' setting of Slic3r, and is only one perimeter thick.  The top and bottom are printed with 20-30% infill and 0.25mm layer thickness.  
The LED ring part slips over the pipe to hold the LED's in place.  The leads are bent 90 degrees.  You will probably have to drill out the holes as most printers are not going to be accurate enough to leave a 0.5mm hole!   
I've included the openscad source so you can tweek anything you want.

comments.text: PLA doesn't hold up to the outside at all in everything I have read and had happen.  Fades lickety split on you whereas my ABS is still almost as colorful 2 years later in the southern heat and humidity.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: I've read conflicting information on the use of PLA outdoors. I know PLA is supposed to be biodegradable, but I've heard that this is a very gradual process mostly observable under lab conditions.  Still, I don't think it would hold up well here in sunny south Florida.  I'll have to just wait and see how well the black ABS withstands the UV from the sun.  I've also been told that clear ABS is very hard to print with, but I've had no problems with it making the lens and the led rings for this project.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: It doesn't hold up well outside in TN either.
comments.author: scharkalvin

comments.text: Well some parts made from PLA have been outside now for almost a year and a half, and show no damage from the weather, though they have been weed wacked to hell.

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
This Smooth Doorway tile was designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. To assemble, you will need approximately 20 gauge wire, or a thick paperclip. If using a paperclip, straighten and poke through the hole, then clip. Then glue the door around the paperclip, using it as a hinge.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.

This tool allowed me to disconnect the Fuel Rail from the Fuel Line on a Jeep Grand Cherokee.

I successfully used this to disconnect the Fuel Rail from the Fuel Line on a Jeep.  
I know there are solutions that use a carved up pen cap or I could've simply bought the eight dollar tool. This was far more fun and I hope someone else can save time or money, or both.  
I did not need to use Fuel Line Pliers. I only had to put a small amount of force to disengage the clamping tabs.  
The Fuel Line outer diameter was 8.25 mm and the inside diameter of the coupling wass 14.5 mm. I made the tool with a .25 clearance.   
You will need to print two of these in order to use.  
The picture in the Gallery shows the positioning of the two halves of the tool. This was after I used them to disconnect.  
Some Notes and/or Warnings:  
The Fuel Rail is under pressure so be sure you properly remove the pressure.  
There is a suprising amount of gas in the Fuel Rail have a way to dispose of it properly.

comments.text: This should also work on other lines with these style quick connect fittings as long as the tube dia. is the same.

description.text: Precise replica of the Commodore VIC-20 cartridge 'Raid on Fort Knox'. I dedicate it to one of my heroes, Elon Musk, who learned to program on a VIC-20. Thanks to Jim Brain for the original cartridge, and to Ismail, Olga and Niels for helping me print the label.

Edit the .scad file. Set EXT_WIDTH to a multiple of your extrusion width. Set ADDSUPPORT to 1 to add manual supports for the internal clips (these are very easy to remove afterwards). Check the results using the 'cut*' functions. Then convert to STL, slice, check your gcode, and print. Optionally wet-polish using increasingly fine sand paper (I went from grit 280 to 5000), then finish with some plastic polish (I used Xerapol, then put on some silicone spray). Print the label and glue it on. Since I had problems printing the two parts directly (difficult overhang), as an experiment I decided to cut each part in two, and glue the results back together with ABS juice. That worked really well, except I was unable to completely get rid of the seams at the edges during polishing. I tried to use ABS juice here as well, but it seems I always end up with what I think are air bubbles trapped inside. I had the same problem with my earlier joystick, thing 30198. Tips very much welcome!

comments.text:
LOL, I too learned to program on a VIC-20.

This is a modification of my exisiting storage drawers. It has lost the ability to change the number of columns but does now have 2 extra drawer widths - double and quad!
.
This allows for larger items to be stored without compromising my original idea of small storage drawers.
. The drawer sizes are:
Half Bin : 25 x 10.5 x 65
Bin : 25 x 24 x 65
Double Bin : 55 x 24 x 65
Quad Bin : 115 x 24 x 65
.
UPDATE 1: Small update to rotate the rack ready for printing.
.
UPDATE 2: Added new drawers with vertical handles, as suggested by ronthomp.
.
UPDATE 3: Added the sizes of the draws in description.
.
Sorry for all the fullstops but I can't seem to get blank lines in my text anymore.

Customise the number and type of rows you would like. The normal, double and quad rows are 27mm high and the half row is 13.5mm. Multiply out as needed and then add 1mm to account for the final top wall thickness. The unit is 121mm wide.
.
So the RackTEST.stl would be:
(273) (13.51) 1 = 95.5mm
.
On a Huxley (the machine I have) the maximum number of normal height rows are 4. On a Mendel that would increase to 7. YMMV on other machines :-)
.
Then print out all the draws you need.

comments.text:
Great idea, I was looking for exactly this item !

author: maffie

description.text:
attempt to replace Cyano Acrylate bottle nozzle.
the good news is the threads work, the bad news is the tip is too big on the larger model to be of much use as a glue tip for CA but may work for white glues. revised file has a much smaller applicator tip for superglues. It printed a little better but the overhang is difficult. Also the tip did not print all the way to the top with my printer for some reason. print the tip portion at 1.1 scale if you have the same bottle to make the cap fit better. revised4 file is has a sloped overhang to fix printing issues on my
printrbot 1405 and is scaled slightly to fit the existing glue cap better. I will try to print it now and see if it works better than the previous model. revised 4 flat is resized for the cap, but with the flat applicator section so that the model can be printed in 2 parts if the overhang does not work out on your printer.

made in Fusion360 work in progress. learning as I go.  
printed best so far at .4 shell thickness and .1 layer thickness.  
The overhang did not print too well on my first print.  I had to print the nozzle separate from the the nut.  I will try to revise to make this unnecessary.  
the revised4 file has a cone shape to try to print in one piece but the flat one is there in case you want to print the nut and the tip separately (I use cura to cutoff the bottom of the model.  
it slices in Repetier better than cura for some reason.  The photo shows how cura did not slice all of the way to the tip.  
rev4 printed ok but I did have to cobble together two gcodes in Cura to get the full model.  I will attach the gcode if it is possible, but basically I sliced the bottom section normally, and the tip I sliced just the outer contour and pasted the two codes together at about slice 380.  
don't bother with the fat tip one unless you have a special use for that one.  it is not so great for superglue, unless you are using a syringe applicator.

comments.author: kengeroo

comments.text: Did the fipple print correctly? Is the chamber fully sealed? I've had a few whistles fail due to the back having a small hole through the layers. You can probably fix this with some judicious usage of a glue. If the fipple didn't print right, it'll probably not work though.
comments.author: kengeroo

comments.text: I tried printing the whistle, but the results were similar to what I get when I try to combine too many things in a print run.  It prints the first few layers fine, then the print head starts knocking in to some of the printed structures and causes the whole job to fail with balls of plastic coils all over the platform.  Any hints on how to keep this from happening?
comments.author: thirdhatch

comments.text: It could be a lot of things. If you're using PLA, I find printing with a desk fan helps prevent curling. Also, fine-tuning your extrusion parameters so you are not over extruding helps. It sounds like you have a curling, warping, or overextrusion problem.
comments.author: thirdhatch

comments.text: I think I found the problem.  It appears my x-axis stepper was skipping, then losing it's position.  It was happening very infrequently when I first got the printer, so I didn't think anything of it, but now I can't print without it skipping, so I am getting it replaced.  Thanks for the feedback!

Attaches GuerillaBeams projectors to any tripod.
Can simply be snapped on and off the projector repeatedly. There are currently 3 versions:
  • flat base
  • quick mount base (42mmx42mm), for cheap tripods with integrated heads. Fits different different Velbon, Hama and similar tripods
  • quick mount base, for Arca Swiss-like clamp heads, experimental, needs testing (by you?)
    • All adapters feature 1/4-20 tripod screw threads.
    Because 3d printed threads are only so good, I recommend using the quick mount adapters for more heavy projectors. Visit https://gbeam.de/products/tripod-adapter/ for more details and ordering printed parts.
    If you are interested in an adapter with 3/8-16-Threads, please tell me.
Designed with Autodesk Inventor. Source files are available on request.

Print vertically, as shown on the pictures. Only this way the part is strong enough and can be printed without support material. Wall strength
0.8mm shell thickness is sufficient to hold normal GuerillaBeams.
For lenses of 200mm and above, 1.2mm walls are recommended. Infill
Some infill is needed to support the screw thread and the top surface.
Take a look at what your slicer generates and then pick a number 7% and 100% that makes you feel happy.

title: Z thread stabilizer for printrbot simple

description.text:
This is yet another add-on for the Printrbot Simple designed to limit wobble of the z axis threaded rod. The intent here was to minimize Z-ribbing in my prints. This piece is based on designs by others here and modified for the dimensions of the Pbot Simple (w large motors). Seems to work for me; your mileage may vary.   
Note: beware that if you print anything taller than about 8.5 cm, the Y axis drive will hit this brace and try and force it up the poles, depending on how far up you place it. Unfortunately a full 10 cm height print will pop the brace right off or compress the top layers of the print. The only solution would be to get longer poles....
This was made in 123D Design using a Mitutoyo caliper to measure dimensions on the Printrbot Simple.

author: idrummond

description.text:
I needed some shelves in my office, so I designed and printed some cool looking shelf brackets!  This is a 3" angle, meant to be used with (2) screws into your shelf and (1) screw into your wall.  Use a board 6" deep or less.  The picture shown is a 5" deep board, 24" wide.  The strength of your shelf with depend mostly on your wall anchors.  I recommend drilling into a stud OR using a 50lb wall anchor.  
Good luck!
Print (2) per shelf, I used 25% density, 3 shells, 3 layers top and bottom.  You will need (2) screws per bracket to mount your board and (1) screw (with anchor!) to mount to the wall.

title: SmartrapCore 1.0 modified Simplex extruder (for Nema 17 & Bowden) V. 0.5

description.text:
I made my own adaptation of the Simplex extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91054) which is used by default on the prototype of the SmartrapCore printer with a Bowden and a Nema17 stepper motor. It's actually small changes, but I needed these :
  • smaller size (no need to waste PLA, right ?)
  • as the insertion hole for the filament is underneath for the Bowden version, I made this hole easier to find (prominent border, and conic shape to make it easier to introduce filament)
  • nut cavities so that it's easier to tighten the latch with bolts without risking to break the plastic. Quite useful when changing filament. You can use it either with or without springs.
    • It works really well with my filament slider / wires holder also designed for the SmartrapCore printer : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755862 ;)
All parts and assembly are described in detail in the Blender file.

title: R/C 1:10 Car Stand for Yokomo with integrated motor cooler.

description.text:
This thing was made for a Yokomo R/C chassis. Feel free to stretch the width for the needs of your car. The integrated fan (40x40mm type) blows fresh air to the motor and cools it down. A small micro switch starts the fan when the car chassis it placed on the stand. It is easier to print the thing in three parts and glue them together.
Note: The fan inlet on the base part is closed because I need that as support structure. It is very thin and can be broke out after printing. This thing was made with Tinkercad.

It is easier to print the thing in three parts and glue them together.   
The fan inlet on the base part is closed because I need that as support structure. It is very thin and can be broke out after printing.  
You can use a standard 40x40mm fan.   
On the fan left side is a little electronic box. Place the fan cable to this box and connect it with the micro switch. You can close the box with a little cover or fill it with hot glue or something else.  
On the bottom side are 4 holes to place some foam.

This design could easily be used as a display stand for something as well, or as a household decoration. This is not designed to be printed as one piece. Print the roof and the floor then print six pillars, they attach with hexagonal pegs. When you print this, please take a photo and submit a "I made this!" so everyone can see how it turned out!

This is designed to be printed on a 200X200X100mm 3D Printer. I would watch out for warping when you print it, because the floor and roof are large flat pieces that may curl up if you aren't careful.

title: Sandmation, Teeter Totter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: "Sandmation, Teeter Totter" is a "sand animated" teeter totter. This thing is my rendition of an antique toy originally presented in "Carpentry And Mechanics For Boys" by A. Neely Hall in 1918. I've taken quite a few liberties in my 3D printed miniaturized version such as to fit the average build area, reduce 3D printed induced friction, maximize run time, and finally to use the heads of the unwitting riders to tap the sand hopper in order to loosen the sand flow. As was the original design, this is a fussy project as it only works correctly with patience and good balance, yet it is still a grand illustration of animated toys available for children almost a hundred years ago. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDA6zitL7MA. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Parts I purchased:  
1) Very fine colored sand (hobby, craft store, Amazon).  
Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp".  After printing, remove the hold down tabs from "Hopper.stl" and "Pivot.stl".  
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  "Pivot.stl" must move freely on its axle.   
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp".  
Comment if you have questions.

Can be easily printed on a round Mini Kossel bed. Designed for use with 15x15 Open Beam Frame extrusions. Also, corrected the symmetry so you can print two, without having to mirror the second one.

Print two spool holders. Parts:
4x VXB 608 ZZ Bearings
4x m3 flat washers
4x m3x8 socket cap screws
4x m3 full nuts The bearings should easily click into place on the mounting posts. Mount both on one of the top frame extrusions, with the bearing facing each other. Place the nuts in the top track of the frame extrusion, line them up, and secure the spoold holders to them using the washers and cap screws.

WARNING! 3D printers print the plastic so it's porous, so bacteria will grow and thrive in the pores after multiple uses. Either coat it in something (lacquer, etc.) or use this as a disposable one! If you don't have a printer or it's under maintenance, consider buying this through my 3D Hub. Link: https://www.3dhubs.com/seattle/hubs/3d-life

title: "Gravity Based" Shoe Storage System - Makes use of unused/wasted space
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Simple shoe storage system that lets you put unused space, like the sides of a cabinet or a narrow wall area to good use. The .stl file is everything required to mount 'one' shoe so print two for a pair or ten to store 5 pairs up a wall. Very simple, looks cool and puts unused space to good use. The system relies on gravity to hold the shoes in place. Shoes are inserted from underneath and the toe rotated so the toe sits slightly lower than the heel. They just sit in place with the heel against the wall and the top of the back of the shoe hooked into the top of the bracket/heel plate. This works because the weight distribution of the shoe in this position is to the front/toe. Gravity makes the toe want to drop and, as the heel is against the back wall that becomes a pivot point which effectively pushes the top of the shoe up into the heel plate area. The heel plate area has been angled forward to lock the shoe in so it can't drop out. In effect, the shoe is held in by it's own weight! To remove shoes from the system just lift the toes and they will (drop out the bottom... so it features a 'quick release' system as well.
Just attach the adjuster brackets (2) to the wall with high strength contact adhesive tape or using a couple of small screws each. Next, screw on the locknuts onto the adjuster bracket followed by the threaded heel plate. Then all that's left to do is adjust to suit the heel thickness of the shoes you want to store in that position and tighten the lock nut gently. Refer to the instructions and images for additional details. TIPS: If using contact adhesive tape (like 3M Command Strips) prepare the area where the bracket is to be applied with isopropyl alcohol. Also, if the PLA printed adjuster is very smooth, the mounting tape may not adhere well. To overcome this lightly sand the surface of the bracket for improved adhesion... or alternatively use a couple of small screws. If you are using tape and have adhesion problems this is probably due to the mounting tape you are using not adhering well to the PLA. If this happens use one small screw in conjunction with the tape If you like this take time to check out my other designs!

The shoe storage system is a minimalistic way to store shoes and take advantage of unused space. The brackets are small so, although most shoes don't weigh a lot individually, use Raft, Std/0.20mm resolution, at least 4 shells and 50% infill to ensure it is strong enough.   
On a Replicator 2 the threads screw together straight away with no clean up other than Raft removal.

Two handed handle to stabilize my GoPro in the underwater environment. The entire handle is disassembleable.
I made two spikes which can be screwed into the bottom of the handle to fix the handle into the sea bottom and record sea eels. The spikes can be screwed into the grips too to raise the camera from the sea bottom. You can also store them in the grips if you turn them in reversed. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/gopro-diver-s-handle

Layer height = 0.1 mm.
100% infill = spikes, mount, grips. Note: the mount does not require support but you have to clean the edges.
20% infill = left & right holder parts. I made the entire model in a more-or-less easy to read openSCAD script so you can easy fit the model dimensions to your need. I also separated the GoPro mount creation script to a single module to help reusing it in other projects. To assemble the handle you will need two 25 mm M5 stainless steel bolts and two M5 nuts. If you prefer imperial sizes you can change it in the script and re-render the holders and the mount.

This is a simple tripod adapter for the Kinect that requires only one non-printed part, a 1/4" x 20tpi jam nut.
I'm marking this as a work-in-progress because some skeinforge configs don't like the STL file.  Mine complains but my Makerbot Cupcake prints the right thing, so it's probably not going to stall anyone else's printer.

Print out one of each file.  If you're printing on a cupcake, it's easiest to print these on their side -- the two holes at the center are small enough relative to the rest of the piece that they won't collapse.   The notch for the cord will be messy, but you can clean that up with a knife.
Before assembling, use a hobby knife to open up the holes for the bolt and the nut.  They're undersized so that it's easy to get a custom fit.
Put the piece with the jam nut on the Kinect first, then slide the other piece over it.  When the holes are lined up, screw in your tripod bolt and you're done.

author: hackable1125

description.text:
Wirelessly powered desk lamp operating at 6.5MHz. This particular coil is optimized to power a 25W, vintage, Tesla globe-style light bulb. Nikola Tesla's wireless power transmission was my inspiration for this project.

  • Featured article at 3DPrint.com: http://3dprint.com/46711/tesla-desk-lamp/

  • Short video and explanation at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YBIbn9LA6PQ
    • Designed by David Choi

In order to power this lamp, you will need to construct at least a 30W resonant induction transmitter. My transmitter is powered by a 30VDC supply. In my setup, I chose 6.5MHz and built the transmitter into the underside of the table. The transmitter is tunable as the receiver is not for aesthetic reasons.  
Do not rescale! I printed with a 5th Gen Replicator. The resonant frequencies will change depending on the inductor geometry. I printed with 3 shells, 15% in-fill and 0.2mm resolution. The parts fit together fine for me. Some CA glue in certain areas will be necessary.  
The receiving spiral inductor is made with ~7.5ft of 1/8" OD copper tubing and has a final form inductance of approximately 14.1uH. The primary inductance coil is a center-tapped 1/4" copper tube of 2 winds and is approximately 0.34uH. An "extra" resonant coil is put into place beneath the table, whose inductance is not important but area is more so, and is tuned to 6.5MHz as well. This 1/4" OD coil improves efficiency. The power is transferred from the secondary resonator to a single copper loop coupling to the resonator which is directly wired to the bulb.  Without going into much detail, two important factors must be addressed. In order to power anything efficiently impedance matching must be top priority. In addition, one helpful equation is the ratio of primary to secondary inductance and input and output voltages given by: Vout = Vin*Sqrt[Ls/Lp], where Lp is the primary inductance and Ls is that of the secondary.  
If there is interest in the circuit I will disclose it, but that is beyond the interests of this website.  
I intentionally chose a vintage Tesla globe-style bulb reconstruction as a commemoration for his work in wireless power transmission. Were I to have chosen an Edison or Marconi bulb, Tesla would be rolling in his ashes. :)  
One of the lamp legs is built in two pieces and has a conduit for the bulb wiring. If you can construct a transmitter, I expect construction of the lamp base to be straight forward.

comments.text: For now use Vladimiro Mazzilli's induction heater circuit which can be found online. I used MRF150 RF transistors, a 0.34uH center-tapped coil, and DPG15I300PA power switching diodes. Make sure your power supply (i used 30VDC) doesn't ramp up and cause latching of the transistors. Use a power switch between the supply and circuit if this occurs.
comments.author: Industrialbass

comments.text: David, do you think this design could function using conductive 3D printer filament for the coils?
comments.author: barnstormstudio

comments.text: Steven, this is a very good question and am very happy you asked it. I have not had any conductive filament to test with but I can tell you this, the air-core inductors used in this design require a diamagnetic material (copper, silver, etc.) whose magnetic properties are of great importance. As well as this, the conductivity and geometry of the filament is very important since skin effect losses may dominate (the current flows mostly on the surface of the conductor at high frequencies which is why I used 1/8" copper tubing). The third property that conductive filament may exhibit at high frequencies is hysteresis. Although I am not certain for conductive filament, it very well may be unsuccessful. If you have conductive PLA, the first test I would run with limited supplies would be an electromagnet construction. Although this would not prove any high frequency effects, it would be a step in the right direction.

comments.author: Sylinv

comments.text: I've tested multiple oscillator circuits in many different configurations. Many with underwhelming results. I am currently working on a better circuit. But if you would like to build what I have please use Vladimiro Mazzilli's induction heater circuit which can be found online (do a quick search in google). It is simple to construct and is one of the more powerful circuits. I nearly went overkill with MRF150's instead of IRFP250's or equivalent. The fact is that I chose to work with 6.5MHz because it is near the recently set standard of 6.78MHz for wireless power. This initially made things more difficult. Design the circuit around the specs I stated in the instructions and have patience tuning.
comments.author: Sylinv

comments.text: Ok thanks for the info ! I'll have a look at that. Just one more question : if I understand well, the lamp is wireless from the table and the bulb is wireless from the lamp ?
comments.author: macakcat

comments.text: The bulb is wireless from the table however it is wired to the outer, single loop coil (there is a place to put the coil in the print). One of the lamp legs is a has a conduit for wiring to the elevated bulb. Due to the relatively "small" size of the receiving spiral coil and the power needed by the bulb, the distance for wireless powering is greatly reduced. Try experimenting with coil rings loaded with LED's to get a feel for the tuning. I recommend at least a 10MHz oscilloscope to help you. The important information is the Vsupply, Lprimary, impedance of load, Vload, and Lsecondary. All of these play crucial parts in the design that's why i stated my values. If you experiment with lower power elements such as LED's, whose properties make them highly efficient in this application, you can power them a couple feet with ease. Depending on the size of the antenna, larger distances can be had. The farthest I've powered was around 12ft.
comments.author: Sylinv

author: bipedal

description.text: This turns an empty Beer bottle into a pretty candle holder

The File has a simple line, BUT Load your beer bottle into your lasercutter with the butt to the y axis, I have a 50Watt Epilog helix and for raster 50% speed and 100% power top-down Stucki (I like stucki for some reason) and for Vector I set it for 40% speed 100% power and 2500 hz. Cut the line. This scores the top of the bottle. A few taps on the score and it should pop right off. Some bottles are thicker (Jack's down home punch) Cut it a few times. I carefully take the sharp off with a dremmel. Next I edit the file. I add what ever design I want, and delete the cut line. I put the bottle bottom back in and cut the design. Sometimes I do a design that is only 2/3 of the glass long, and 1/2 the glass wide, I cut it, turn the glass around and rotate it 90deg and cut again. That way I get the same image, mirror image and fully wrapped around. Play and enjoy!

author: JuanVL

description.text: The Jade Robot Gripper/Camera Mount was created to provide users with a simulated remote control rover experience. The gripper along with the remote control ("Jade Action") software, provides a fun and educational robot experience. The mounting plate is designed with the Lynxmotion hole pattern, so this design can be added to other Lynxmotion robots without modification. Note that the camera is mounted with the gripper so that when the gripper is lowered to pick up an object, the camera moves with it, changing it's field of view and eliminating the need for a separate camera for the gripper. You can watch it in action here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=quSBaofYo88 Software to use these grippers with the Jade Robot is available from Mimetics (https://www.mimetics.ca) free of charge. Email me ([email protected]) with any questions.

An assembly drawing is included in the files for this Instructable. The servos used for the initial builds are HiTech HS-422 (standard size and operating servos). The camera used with this assembly is the Electronics123 C329 (http://www.electronics123.com/kits-and-modules/c328-and-c329-cameras/C329-UART-board-Color-JPEG-Compression-VGA-Camera-Module.html) with L36IR Lens (http://www.electronics123.com/kits-and-modules/tv-video-and-camera/L36IR-Lens-Holder-with-Screws-for-C329-Cameras.html) Screws listed in the Assembly drawing are from McMaster-Carr and the part number identification is:
90184A050 - #2, 1/4" Panhead screws
90184A100 - #4, 1/4" Panhead screws
90184A105 - #4, 3/8" Panhead screws For the actual gripper, we recommend using a Staples brand white rubber eraser (P/N: 11255) cut down the middle and then cut to 45mm long and fastened in the gripper cuts with with #2 1/4" screws. For best operation, drive servos at intermediate position and assemble the elevation unit and grippers with the indentations lined up.

This calibration object was made to fulfill the need to manually calibrate a XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 with 0.92 repetier firmware. The sample .stl file is made for the Da Vinci 1.0 printer with 5mm height. Customize this object in Makerbot Customizer or OpenSCAD PS: This is my first OpenSCAD project, suggestions are greatly appreciated. Please let me know if you have made, or plan to make it!

• Customize your own calibrator with Makerbot Customizer.
    • Make the object dimensions a bit smaller than your maximum print size (ex: 150mmx150mm calibrator for a 200mmx200mm printbed).
  • Download the customized .stl and start the printjob.
  • As it's printing, adjust the bed height so that all the circles and lines have the same width (a photo will be attached in a future update).
  • The plastic should stick to the bed without glue (especially with the Da Vinci 1.0 printer, which came with a gluestick; I'm not a fan of sticky plastic).
    • Note: The default settings are set for Da Vinci 1.0 printer with 5mm height (1mm height version is also included, as it takes a lot less time to finish printing).

Customizable options include: General -
  • Print Bed dimensions
  • Object height
  • Number of rings along the x and y
    • Ring -
  • Outer Radius
  • Inner Radius
  • Resolution
    • Connector -
  • Connector width (thickness)
Fiddle around with the settings, let me know through Twitter or GitHub if you have any questions or comments.

author: DodgyDave80

description.text: Desk drawn for school project.

This is a CDR file to be used with a laser cutter.  I exported from X7 as a version 11 file so more people could access the file.  
I decided to organize my samples so I could more easily store and get to them.  The upper part is sized and marked for an Avery #8560 commonly available at any office supply store.  
The top tabs are meant to hang on a pegboard hook.  The top shape easily identifies the class of the filament.  Square for ABS, Rounded for PLA, House shaped for Nylon and Triangular for Other.  
I mark the product name, its color and print temperature ranges on the label for easy reference.  
Another use for these is to hang them on the outside of your bucket(or other storage container) to show whats inside it.  Less opening sealed containers that way.  
The corel file has all the components needed to make additional shaped tabs if you want to expand your collection.

Blue - Etch
Yellow - Dotted line
Orange - Cut first
Red - Perimeter cut Set your laser to etch 3/4 of the way through whatever material you choose to use (I used 3mm ply) for the blue etch layer. The dotted line should just mark the surface so you know where to apply the label. Orange and red are full cut through. Once you cut these out, simply use a hot glue gun to affix a sample piece of filament into the groove at the bottom. Then write/print and attach the label to the top.

title: Simple Shotglass
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Modeled from caliper measurements I took of a traditional shotglass, this 3D printed ABS version is watertight and impervious to being dissolved by alcohol.  
Having only the most basic training in chemistry, I wasn't sure ABS would hold up to highly concentrated ethanol, so I did an experiment.  I filled the shotglass with denatured alcohol (pure ethanol tainted with a little methanol to kill you if you drink it... required by U.S. law, believe it or not).  I left the denatured alcohol in the shotglass for two hours.  When the time was up, I strained the shotglass' contents through a paper towel into a clear plastic cup.  I examined the paper towel for any black ABS residue.  Finding none, I examined the contents of the cup.  The solution appeared perfectly clear.  Therefore, I concluded, it is unlikely that ethanol dissolves ABS.  
I know from experience that acetone dissolves ABS instantly, so the violent reaction I feared did not take place.  I believe that if printed in ABS, this shotglass will be safe to drink out of.

Printed on "fine" resolution with a LulzBot Taz 4.  Took about 4 hours on that setting (would probably take less than an hour on "fast").  There's a thick block of plastic at the base, which is probably what takes the most time / filament.

comments.text:
I do not have any training in the chemistry of polymers
However, everything that I have read since I have been using my 3D printer has indicated that abs is not food safe.
Food products made of abs can leach compounds
Additionally, 3D printed items have imperfect surfaces that can harbor bacterial growth when they come in contact with food.
of course this is probably not a huge issue when alcohol is being stored in the cup.
comments.author: craigj

comments.text: thanks for the input - your concerns align with my own.  a shotglass is not really intended for "storage" of alcohol, so hopefully the 2 seconds between pouring the shot and killing it isn't enough time for it to leach anything toxic into the drink.  my experiments proved to my satisfaction that alcohol does not dissolve ABS like acetone does, and no visible ABS residue was observed after soaking in pure alcohol for several hours, so i'm not too worried.  i definitely would not drink hot coffee out of a printed mug.  high temperatures are known to release synthetic estrogens and other endocrine disruptors (e.g. bisphenol A, a.k.a. BPA) from polymers.  no thanks!
comments.author: craigj

author: AwesomeA

description.text: A Single Track Tunnel Portal.

Intended to be used with the excellent OpenForge dungeon wall sets or 28mm miniatures.
These models are things you might find in a wizard's lab. The books are intended to be "assembled" into the book shelves. Print them out separately, paint the spines, and then glue them to the shelves. I made a few versions so it is not the same pattern of books over and over. You can flip them around too so there is essentially 6 different patterns so you can make a lot of combinations. The open book can be placed on the podium or wherever else you want. The bottles are tricky because they are so small. Sometimes the print turns out and sometimes not. Fine with me, they are tiny and take almost no time to print. Increasing the scale would help a lot but then you've got giant bottles. As with the open book, glue them on other pieces to customize. Put them in/on the bookshelves, on a dresser, wherever, just have fun with it. I made two versions of the wizard's desk in case the pentagram bothers you. More to come.

This file is a free download.  Since it is listed as 'creative commons - attribution' there are very few restrictions on how you use these files.  You are welcome (and encouraged) to print them out for yourself for personal use.  You are also allowed to buy and sell physical copies of the models.  However, if you use my files and my pictures you should provide a link back to where you got them. Thanks.

remixed_from.author: garyacrowellsr
remixed_from.title: Power Supply Mounting for the Replicator

title: Power Supply Mounting for the Replicator, revisited

description.text:
This Thing is a simple drilling guide to aid in mounting a common 24V, 360W switching power supply beneath the build chamber of a Replicator or similar printer.  This would replace the external brick power supply  
Besides the drill hole locations, the guide includes the 'extents' of the power supply to aid in placement, and it can be used as standoffs so that the vent holes on the supply won't be blocked by the mounting surface.  
A second guide is included for a 60W power supply.  This is a 12V supply for some fans and other accessories I plan to add.
This is a rework of the earlier thing in that it adds the extents and the second guide.  
EDIT, 3/1/15:  added drill and marking guide for popular power entry/switch/fuse module.

Printed in ABS at 0.2mm, 25% infill.  The width and thickness of the frame that I used are probably overkill; they can be reduced in the OpenSCAD files.  
The 360W power supply mounts with 4mm screws, the 60W with 3mm screws.  Ensure that the ends of the screws that penetrate the power supplies do not extend more than 3.5mm into the case.  Adjust the screw lengths, standoffs, and washers to achieve this.  
The 'extent' frames are just to aid in initial positioning as shown in the picture.  They may be broken off after the holes are marked.  The smaller power supply doesn't need standoffs, so the entire guide can be disposed of after marking.  Printing the larger extent frame is a pretty good bed leveling test, but it doesn't have to be perfect.  
The picture shows the frames taped in place, prior to marking/drilling.  The 60W supply provides 12V for some other devices that I intend to add to the printer.  The box in the upper right corner is a front-panel mounted thermostat, that is controlling a small AC heater placed in the build chamber.  A switched, fused IEC AC input module will be mounted in the upper left corner.  
Edit on 3/1/15:  I've added a drill and marking guide for a popular power entry/switch/fuse module.  I'll use this to mark and mount the switch on the back panel near the new power supply screw terminals.  As with the other guides, it includes a square frame to make it easier to square up the (non-square) module.  I'll also be adding a 3-terminal barrier strip to distribute the AC securely.  I'll add pics and a diagram of the wiring when I get that done.  The switch is a pretty easy to find on ebay; search: "iec power entry module fuse switch" and it should come right up.  Inexpensive, but seems sturdy enough.
